She may still be the ''Queen of Mean'' to some people, but Leona M. Helmsley has a soft spot for animals. And she wants to show that to New York by financing the construction of a nonprofit animal hospital.

This may come as a surprise to those who remember Mrs. Helmsley, heir to Harry B. Helmsley's fortune, as the arrogant and wrathful matron of the Helmsley hotel chain. To many, she remains a symbol of unfeeling hubris.

''We don't pay taxes. Only the little people pay taxes,'' is the infamous quote attributed to her by a former housekeeper when Mrs. Helmsley was convicted of tax evasion in the early 1990's. She served 18 months in prison.

Her reputation suffered anew in 2002, when a former employee sued Mrs. Helmsley, saying she had fired him because he is gay. A jury awarded the plaintiff $11.7 million after a three-week trial in January 2003, but a judge later reduced the amount to $554,000, along with $638,000 in legal fees and expenses.

Mrs. Helmsley, now 84, can well afford to pay that -- and her taxes, too. Her real estate holdings, including the Park Lane Hotel, where she lives, are worth an estimated $4 billion, and she ranks 247th on Forbes's list of the world's richest people.
She declined to be interviewed in person for this article, agreeing only to respond to questions through her longtime spokesman, Harry Rubenstein.

''She is still in charge and she makes decisions with a group of advisers,'' Mr. Rubenstein said. ''Most of her buildings are held in partnership form and the partners have supervisors. She loves the Park Lane, which she owns without a partner. She watches over the kitchen, the elevators and does her own inspections of the rooms. Sometimes she greets patrons.''

And she loves her pet, a Maltese named Trouble, who appears in advertisements for the Park Lane. Mrs. Helmsley's idea to build an animal hospital -- a project she said she had begun to consider recently -- is aimed at helping creatures less fortunate than her pampered companion, Mr. Rubenstein said.
Those pets would presumably be owned by people who may pay taxes but can't afford to stay at the Park Lane.
